H0.text: Some diseases can be treated is a positive effect of William Perkins’ 1856 discovery that he could produce purple dye from coal, an alternative to the sea‑animal source used many years earlier.

H1.text: Purple clothing can be made because William Perkins discovered how to produce purple dye from coal in 1856, providing a new source after many years of using sea animals.

H2.text: Sea animals are not needed to make purple dye, as William Perkins discovered a coal-based method in 1856.

H3.text: Perkins is famous for discovering a new medicine is a positive effect of his 1856 discovery that he could make purple dye from coal, after purple dye had previously been made from sea animals.

A4.text: Suitable as a dye of silk and other textiles, it was patented by Perkin

A5.text: It was discovered serendipitously by William Henry Perkin in 1856 while he was attempting to synthesise the phytochemical quinine for the treatment of malaria
